div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
THE TSAR FORGIVES
div.p: St. Petersburg, February 1. The police yesterday surprised a meeting of strickers in a tavern. They fired upon the people; killing a girl and wounding four men. A supplementary official statement give the number of killed on the 22nd ult. as 96, and the wounded 333, of whom 32 died. {R.)

Warsaw, February 1. The number of killed and wounded during the recent disturbances here are variously estimated at from 500 to 1,200. The former is the more probable figure. There are still occasional exchanges of shots in the suburbs. (R.)

St. Petersburg, February 1. The Tsar has received a delegation of workmen. He told them that he pardoned the revolt, and that he would try and better their condition. Prince Mirsky has been relieved of his functions at his own request. (Havas.)
Warsaw, February 1. Quiet has been restored, and work is being resumed. (Havas.)

St. Petersburg, February 1. Today the Tsar will receive a deputation of workmen at Tsarkoe Seto. Except at Warsaw, where there is will considerable torment; the Russian provinces seem to be generally settling down. Well-informed persons believe, however, that the effects on the movement will be lasting, as it shows a remarkable ana unsuspected vitality of co-operation among the Russian masses, which is likely to manage itself whenever occasion arises. The deputation to the Tsar numbered 34. They were accompanied by Generals Kokovstself aud Trepott. The Tsar said that the incident, the deplorable consequences of which were inevitable as the result of disorder, were due to the workmen permitting themselves to be misled by traitors. Strikes and demonstrations constantly resulted in disorders which must always no repressed by troops, He recognised that the workmen's lives were not easy, but they must be patient. It was a crime to come in crowds to declare their needs to him. He promised to take measures to amenorate their lot and to assure a legal examination of their demands. The Tsar concluded: —"1 pardon your transgression. Return to work and do your duty." (Reuter.)

div.head: OUTRAGE AT ODESSA.
div.p: Odessa, February 1. An attempt to assassinate the Chief of Police here was made today. The chief was wounded by a revolver shot. The assailant has been arrested. (Reuter.)

div.head: HEAVY RUSSIAN CASUALTIES SANDEPU' IGNITED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, February 1. General Sakharoff estimates the Japanese prisoners at over 300. (Reuter.)
London, February 1. The “Daily Telegraph" learns from Tokio that the Russian casualties from the 25th to the 29th ult. are now estimated at from 36,000 to 42,000, and the Japanese 7,000. (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, February 1. General Kuropatkin cables that on the 31st ult. Sandepu was ignited as a result of the Russian cannonade, thus compelling the Japanese to partially evacuate it. The Japanese attacks on the neighbouring villages and passes were repulsed. (Reuter.)

div.head: RESIGNATION OF PRINCE MIRSKI.
div.p: St. Petersburg, February 1. Prince Mirski, Minister of the Interior, has finally resigned. (Reuter.)

div.head: HUNGARIAN CABINET CRISIS.
div.p: Budapest, February 1. Count Tisza has resigned. (Reuter.)
Vienna, February 1. Count Tisza has handed in the Cabinet’s resignation. (Havas.)

LOCAL AND GENERAL The Ibrahimieh Canal was re-opened on Saturday last. The Post Office at Ibrahimieh (Ramleh) has been admitted to the inland and foreign money order service. The P.0. Liner "Osiris” entered the Khedivial Mail S.S. and Graving Dock Company’s pontoon at Alexandria this morning.
Quail Exports-The total value of the quails exported from Egypt during the last twelve months was LE. 9,873, as against LE. 10,169 in 1903.
Ottoman Bane Theft—The theft of LE 1,000 from the Ottoman Bank is still the subject of an enquiry, but so far no results have rewarded the police.
Lots Turcs — The Credit Lyonnais informs us that at yesterday’s drawing of the Ottoman Railway Lottery, the holder of bond No. 1,841,389 was the winner of the "gros lot”

Alhambra Theatre.—Two debuts are announced for this evening, while Lumiere et Tenebre is meeting with continued success. A ball will take place after the performance this evening. The Fitzner Quatuorgave a most successful recital at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, yesterday evening. Tomorrow evening they will appear at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo.

Suez Canal— On the 30th January 13 vessels passed through the Canal, of which 9 were British, 2 Dutch, 2 Italian. The receipts for the day were frs. 313,398.67. The total amount received in dues from January 1 to 30 was frs. 10,776,436.32 Annoucements that they are opening a house at Cairo under the same name as here, viz., R. J. Moss Co. In respect of the business of their Cairo house, they have admitted into partnership and entrusted its direction to Mr. John C. Cavafy, who for many years has held their confidence and occupied a position of trust with them at Alexandria.

Cairo Tragedy— An enquiry has been opened by the Cairo police into the circumstances attending the death of an Armenian, Serkis Papayian, who died in Abbaasieh Hospital on Monday from wounds inflicted in a murderous attack. A certain Michel Marxian has been arrested on suspicion of being his assassin.

Egyptian Investment and Agency, Limited. —The “Pall Mail Gazette." in discussing the prospectus of this company, says: There ought to be plenty of opportunities for a business of this kind, and the company seems to start with everything in its favor. It is not often the public are allowed to come in on the same footing as the promoters, and we sincerely hope that the experiment will be justified by brilliant success.

Bank or Egypt.— The directors recommend a further dividend of 6 per cent. making 10 per cent for the year ended December 31, and also a bonus of 15s per share on the old shares, and on the new shares one-fourth of the dividend and bonus for the year, less the interim dividend paid in July last on the other shares, after adding £170,000 to the reserve, including premium on new shares, leaving £12,643 to be carried forward. For 1903 the dividend was the same, but the bonus was 10s. per share.

Abbas Helmy Theatre.—There are few artistes who exercise such a fascination over the public as does Signora Bellincioni, who gives the first of a series of five performances at the Abbas this evening. And this is but natural. Her talent is immense ; her interpretations are always original, always fascinating, always in keeping with her enormous talent as an actress and a singer. Her voice is of the softest; her manner of phrasing is an example of elegance and good taste. The expression of her singing is grand, her art conquers and enchants ; she is an artiste in every sense of the word, and no one should miss seeing her in Traviata, in which she has acquired fame.

Tourist Steamers. — The White Star liner “Republic,” which arrived at Alexandria yesterday from New York and Naples,made a remark ably quick passage from the Utter port, whence she sailed on Sunday afternoon at 4 o’clock, thus accomplishing the voyage in 67 hours. She had 235 passengers on board. Readers of this paper will observe in our advertising columns particulars of the sailings of the vessels of the White Star Line from Alexandria to Naples (reached in four days) and America. This service is undoubtedly one of the best for reaching Europe and should be well patronised by the many travellers nowin Egypt, who will soon be contemplating their return journey. The immediate sailings are : S.S.. “ Romanic" (11,400 tons) Feb. 16; S.S. “ Canopic ” (18,000 tons) Mar. 9 ; S.S. “ Republic ” (15,400 tons) Mar. 16 ;S.S. “ Romanic ” (11,400 tons) Mar. 30, and the fares from Alexandria to Naples are £10 and upwards. Bookings may be effected at the White Star agents in Alexandria, Messrs J. Ross and Co., and at Cook’s Tourist Offices, in Cairo.

div.head: RAMLEH RAILWAY COMPANY. THE CITY EXTENSION.
div.p: A number of complaints have lately been made by the public against the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company on the subject of the want of accommodation at the temporary terminus of the line at Alexandria. Owing to the recent bad weather these complaints became very rife, because there was no shelter at all at the terminus. The company, it is only just to state, has for some months past been urging the Alexandria Municipality to grant provisionally permission to make a turning-point (bonde) and a shelter for passengers at the new terminus in order that the trams should not have to wait, and that thereby accident might be avoided. The compauy asked that this request should be granted until some decision was arrived at on the subject of the new city terminus in Mohamed Aly-square. The Municipality refused to consider the question unless the company gave them a supervisory control over the line in the interests of the publics. But according to the company’s concession this control was vetted in the Egyptian Government, and the board of directors of the compauy has no power to resign this right to the Municipality, as it is the fundamental part of the concession. At the present moment, therefore, the state of affairs is as follows. The Municipality has given the company the power to extend the line to the square according to the contract for the cession of the land for extending the Ramleh-boulevard. But the Municipality has not yet come to any decision as to the actual terminus of the proposed extension of the line into the city. In the meantime it refuses to let the company make a provisional terminus by the old station. The inconvenience resulting from this state of things is obvious, and it is sincerely to be hoped that the Municipality will find some means to solve the difficulty.

div.head: THE RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: Shebin-el-Kom, January 30. For a long time past the traffic to Tantah on the Ashmonn-Tantah line has been very heavy, especially on Fridays and Mondays, when large numbers of the fellaheen visit Tantah for the purpose of praying in the famous Mosque of Sidi Ahmed el-Bedawi. To provide for this heavy traffic, the Administration in the begin-ing of the year put on a 3rd-claas special train. This was a great boon to the inhabitants of this province also as it gave them an opportunity of joining the express to Cairo and Alexandria at Tantah at 9 am. For some reason or other, this train has now been discontinued, and in its place an engine and three carriages have been added to the ordinary train which leaves Ashmoun at 8.40 am. for Tantah and returns from Tantah at 6.30 pm. Therefore anyone travelling from Ashmoun or any intermediate station with the intention of going on to Alexandria or Cairo, must sleep at Tantah all night if be desires to reach his destination at an early hour in order to transact his business and return the same day. The Administration is increasing it expenditure without increasing the utility of the line so for as the passengers are concerned. We would draw the attention of the Administration to this matter, and urge it to run the extra carriage and engine as a special train starting from Ashmoun at 6 a.m. in the morning and returning from Tantah at 4.40 pm.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will attend prayers at Mariout Mosque to-morrow, H.E the Governor being in attendance. His Highness will hold a reception at Abdeen Palace on Monday, 13th inst The reception will be reserved for those who have recently received grades and decorations from his Highness.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: The Legislative Council will meet on Saturday next. Yesterday it took cognisance of a note from the Ministry of the Interior announcing the election of five new members.

div.head: MOTOR BUS SERVICE.
div.p: It is to be hoped that the Alexandria Municipality will be careful, before sanctioning motor bases in Alexandria, to draw up an elaborate set of regulations for strict observance by the concessionaire company who propose to start the innovation. Unless most careful rules and regulations are made, our main roads will be unsafe for man or beast,and cabs and private carriages will be driven from the streets by the instinct of self-preservation. For as matters at present stand anybody can be a driver of a motor and there is no system of examination or licenses for chauffeurs. It is appalling to contemplate the results of a service of rapid motor bases careering wildly through the busiest parts of the city coder the guidance of irresponsible native driven. We are decidedly in favour of a motor bus service for Alexandria, and we think, if properly worked, it would be a great boon to the city and suburbs, but before sanctioning it the Municipality ought to impose the most strongest conditions with a view to public safety.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Manage ment Moderate charges. Patronised by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: S.S. “FORTUNA” REPORTED TOTALLY LOOT.
div.p: Rumours are afloat that the S.S. “Fortuna,” formerly of the Bell’s Asia Minor Line, has become a total wreck in the Red Sea.

div.head: UNHAPPY STATE EMPLOYES.
div.p: We are authorised to state that the Commission which is at present enquiring into the position of the smaller employes of the various Government departments, is taking into consideration the claims of the telegraphists with those of the employes of the other branches of the public service. The telegraphists will be treated in exactly the same way as the employes of the various Ministries, who have petitioned for an increase of pay. Their claims will be examined and, if substantiated, satisfied.

div.head: FRENCH CHARITY BAZAAR
div.p: Tuesday's Charity Bazaar at the French Agency was an entire success. The large salon and the patio of the Agency had been decorated with great taste for the occasion, the fair members of the French colony who sold at the different stalls made the most charming and persuasive of saleswomen, and their efforts were crowned with well-deserved success, a large sum having been netted for the orphans and the aged or ailing poor. M. de la Bouliniere was unable to preside over the function owing to his recent sad bereavement, but his place was ably filled by Mme. de la Bouliniere and her daughters, who received their numerous visitors and presided over the bazaar with their accustomed amiability and graciousness, assisted by MM. Lecomte, Prevost, Quercy, and de Vitasse, of the French Agency. The first visitors were Princess Hussein and the Princess of the Khedivial Family, and later in the afternoon Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, Mazloum Pasha, Ghazi Ahmed Mukhtar Pasha, Lady Cromer, M. and Mlle. Gennadis, General de Negrier, M. and Mme Bousquet, with the personnel of the French Consulate and numbers of other prominent members of the French and of the foreign colony generally, were there and it was not till 7 p.m. that the bazaar was over. The drawing of the lottery tickets taken will take place on the 5th inst.

div.head: VERDI THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: The Verdi Theatre company gave their farewell performance "I Puritani" on Sunday night; and we may say that it can rank with anything they have so far given us. Signor Tomisani was charming, above all during the 3rd act Signor Baldelli was excellent, and Signor Borteoni—who usually has had only minor parts—was most creditable. Signora Svicher was as wonderful as ever, and she added to her lustre by a special performance of a fantasia by Offenbach. We may say at once that her mastery over this (and, we under stand, other instruments) is fully as great as that over her voice. The “harmonics" were extraordinary, not merely as a “tour de force” bet for delicacy and tone. It is not given to every cellist to prodoce faultless violin effects on a violoncello ; therein not merely skill but also a considerable knowledge of music is involved. And the rest of her playing was artistic, quiet, and indeed thoroughly admirable. We understand that the company will, after their present visit to Alexandria, return to Cairo, and that, among the pieces to be given, Mignon will figure. We have, in these columns, said much about the excellence of the Verdi Theatre, and unfortunately have had occassion to compare it with the Khedivial Opera, most unfavorably (but deservedly so) as for as the latter is concerned. The Verdi Theatre has given us Signora Svicher and Signori Tomisani, Bal-delli, and Badini, four singers of unusual merit. And we sincerely hope that the company will, on their return, meet with a more appreciative—we bad almost said less churlish —reception, and that Cairo may bo induced by experience to believe that opera (and good opera) may be obtainable independently of abonnement and State subsidy. To conclude, we may hazard a prophecy that if the Compagnia Lirica is appreciated and remunerated according to its undoubted deserts, it will be enabled thereby to afford a chorus and general ensemble worthy to support and enhance the merits of its excellent “principals.” We quite agree with the “Journal du Caire” that the chorus and staging of the Khedivial Theatre beyond reproach. The orchestra is not so much so, witness the Tristan et Isolde, though it is numerous and well organised. Naturally the one theatre can and the other oannot indulge in these luxurious necessities. And once more we repeat that the Verdi Theatre management deserve the highest possible praise for the good work they have done. That they should be at all comparable with, not to say at time* better than, the Khedivial Theatre is the best possible testimony to the excellence of that work.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Asiatic Prince,” from Manchester, left Malta on Wednesday and is due here on Sunday next, with passengers and general cargo. The S.S. "Creole Prince" arrived in Manchester from Alexandria on Wednesday last. The Messageries Maritimes S.S. “Sydney” arrived at Alexandria from Marseilles at 2 a.m. yesterday.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Djemil Pasha Toussoun. Turkish Ambassador at Vienna, arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Cairo en route for Europe. Princess Said Bey Toussoun has left London and embarks on the P.O. Rfl. “Isis" at Brindisi. Her Highness 'hopes to be in Cairo on the 8th inst, and will, as usual, take up her residence at the Ghexireh Palace Hotel The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire have chartered Messrs. Cook’s dahabieh “Hathor" for a trip up the river. Lord Cromer leaves Cairo on Friday or Saturday for a dahabieh excursion up the river which will last a fortnight Hon. John Ward, equerry to the King and brother of the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, who recently underwent a successful operation for appendicitis, arrived at Cairo yesterday evening. The Savoy Restaurant has now every evening the aspect of being en fete, all the tables being engaged. Yesterday evening. Sir Ernest Camel entertained a large party, including the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, Lord and Lady Howe, Birch Pacha, Major General Sir Stanley Clarke and Sir Edward and Lady Colebrooke. At another table we noticed Mr. W. Heaton Armstrong and a party, including Mr. Machell. Maitie Carton de Wiart, the Hon. 0. Murray, Master of Elibank, Mr. Hobhouse, M.P., Johnson Pasha, and Col. Clark. Mr. and the Misses Zakrewsky entertained a large party, including M. and Mme. Maximoff, M. and Hoeltzke, and Baron von Haeften. Mme. Wetzlar entertained Com. Clician and Marchese di Rudini. We also noticed Major Pine and Mr. Carter Wilson, Count Kozsiebrodski and party, Lord and Lady Dalhousie, Princesse Bonaparte de la Moshowa, Count Primoli, Count de Clary, etc. The latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel include Sir Ernest C easel and party, including Mrs. Ceasel and Lord and Lady Howe, Sir Edward and Lady Colebrooke, Dr. Scott and Lady Sarah Wilson. Other arrivals are Major Pirie, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martin, New York, Mrs. and Miss Whelen, Mr Xavier Charmes, Mr. David King, Messrs. Arthur and Francklin Beebe, Miss Devahl, etc. Lady Colebrooke, who has come to Egypt as one of Sir Ernest Cassel’s party, prior to once more taking up the role of political hostess, proposes daring the coming session, it is. reported, to revive the party salon of a generation or so ago; convinced that so far at least as the Liberal cause is concerned, society is not rendering to politics its full meed of duty. It is something over two years ago that Sir Edward and Lady Colebrooke first opened the doors of their charming house in Stratford-place to the liberal League with Lord Rossbery as the lion of the evening. As a political hostess, Lady Colebrooke was a signal success as she has always been in a purely social sense, for she has wit, sympathy, and beauty. Lady Colebrooke is a daughter of the late Lord Alfred Paget, and is a cousin of the Marquess of Anglesey. The King and Queen stood sponsors at her christening, and attended her marriage in 1889. Sir Edward, who is forty-three or thereabouts, is the fifth baronet of a creation of 1759; and is the owner of some thirty thousand acres. Among the passengers for Egypt by the “Marmora" is Mr. H. T. Anstruther, who is bound for Ismailia. He is one of the official directors of the Suez Canal Company and will take part in the annual inspection of the canal by the directors. He is accompanied by his wife, the Hon. Mrs. Anstiuther, who is a daughter of the 4th Baron Sudely. Boutros Pasha Ghali, Mr. Malcolm Mellwraith, M. de Rocca Serra, and M. Bernardi left Cairo last night to attend the last meeting ot the technical commission or the Mixed Tribunals. The marriage of Neghib Bey Fehmy, the son of Scandar Pasha Fehmy, to Miss Abontxia was celebrated at Zeitoun on Tuesday. We regret to lean that Miss Friend, eldest daughter of Mr. E. C. Friend, of Max, had a nasty fall while out riding, and dislocated her right elbow. She is, however, progressing satisfactorily. Dr. Giffen, American missionary in the Sudan, is expected to arrive from America next Tuesday by the Messageries Maritimes Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice- Sir Thomas Lipton, Major Johnstone, Mr. Fleming Burnyeate, Mr. Longworth, Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Lee, Mr. and Mrs. Johnson, Mr. W. Bales Header, Exellen von Blucher and daughters, Admiral Alfred F. Dale and Miss Dole, Mr. Clifford, Mr. and Mrs. Nichols, Major de Winton, Major Hickman, Mr. and Mrs. Dymond, Mrs. Taylor, Capt Sherbrooke, Mr. Lesly Bayley, Major and Mrs. Lombe, Mr. B. G. Thornton, Mr. Bernheim, Mr. and Mrs. W. and Miss Campbell, Mr. Smulders.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: H.S.C. SECOND WINTER MEETING.

In connection with the above, which will take place at Helonan on the race course adjoining the Tewfik Palace Hotel on Saturday next, the management of the Tewfik issue Tewfik race coupons at P.T. 55 for visitors and P.T. 40 for ladies, to include 1st class rail to Helouan, luncheon at the Tewfik Palace, entrance to grand-stand and paddock, afternoon tea in members' enclosure, and 1st class rail to Cairo. These coupons are sale at the booking office (Cairo), Bab-el-Louk, but to facilitate matters for the public and avoid the usual rush at the station on race day, arrangements have been made for them to be also, on any day previous to the races, at Stephenson and Co’s, English chemists, Operasquare, Cairo. A military band will be in attendance, as on previous occasions. The following is the lunch programme. 1. Polonaise— Chopin 2. Overture-Emma de Resburgo 3. Value-Soiree d'Ete 4. Selection-La Poupee-Audran 5. Sketch-By the Swanee River-Myddalton 6. Valse-Sabre las Olas-Rosas The following program will be played during the races: 1. March-Imperial Edward-Sousa 2. Overture-Romantique-Bela 3. Valse-The Distant Shore-D'Albert 4. Selection-The Belle of New York 5. Polonaise-Mashen 6. Toreader et Andalose-Rubenstein. 7. Valse-Ballseeggez-Chabulka Moustafa Effendi el Aishy, Infantry Band.

div.head: BILLIARDS.
div.p: On Monday and Tuesday, 6th and 7th inst, a billiard match of 1,200 up will be played at the Grand Hotel Continental between Mr. Jose Ortiz, champion of Spain, and Mr. B. Melikian, champion of Egypt. Calendar of Coming Events.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: February. Thurs. 2 Zizinia Theatre. French comedy company in Oiseaux de Passage. 9 p.m. Abbas Helmy Theatre. Italian Opera Company in La Traviata, 9.30 pm. Fri. 3 Alderson’s Garden. Variety Entertainment 4 pm. Football Ras-el-Tin School Grounds. Cup Tie. Yacoub Pasha Artin’s Cop for Lower Egypt Government Schools Ras-el-Tin. Da-manhour. Kick off 3.30 p.m. Zizinia Theatre. Armenian Benevolent Society. Benefit performance of Le Petit Lord. 9pm. Sat 4. A.C.C. ground. Cricket. A.C.C. R. Berks XI. l.45 p.m. sharp St Andrew F.C. Captain’s XL Vice-Captain’s IX. Opening of New Ground Mobarrem Bey New Khedivial Hotel Professor Felix’s Concert 9.15 pm. CAIRO.

February, Thurs. 2 Khedivial Opera House. Italian Opera Company in Adrienne Lecouvreur. 9 pm. Theatre des Nouveantes. Variety Entertainment 9.30 pm. Trocadero. Variety Entertainment. 9.3O pm. Ghezireh Pekoe Hotel. Small Dance 10 pm. Fri. 3 Mena House. Gymkhana. 3 pm. Zoological Gardens. Performance by Ghizeh Boys’ Band in afternoon. Ezbet Gourgi Point-to-Point Races Sat 4 Helouan Second Winter Race Meeting. 2.30 pm. School of Medicine. Lecture on Sleeping Sickness by Capt Grieg. 4 pm. Shepheard’s Hotel. Band Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers. 4 to 6 p.m. Savoy Hotel Small Dance. 10 pm.

div.head: P. PLUNKET PROPRIETOR. DIRECT IMPORTER OF BRITISH And IRISH TEXTILE MANUFACTURES.
div.p: Ladies' Fanoy Silk Blouses and Skirts, and Fanny Material for Evening Wear. Also Fans, Fancy Pins, Artificial Flowers, Pearl necklets and Chiffons. Ladies’ and Gents’ Pocket Handkerchiefs In Real Irish Linen.
